stem: The nurse is preparing to mix Regular (short-acting) and NPH (intermediate-acting) insulin in a single syringe. Place the steps in the correct order.

options.text: Inject air into the NPH vial equal to the prescribed dose.
Withdraw the prescribed dose of NPH insulin.
Inject air into the Regular vial equal to the prescribed dose.
Withdraw the prescribed dose of Regular insulin.

rationale.correct: Mixing technique prevents cross-contamination of vials. (1) Air into 'Cloudy' (NPH). (2) Air into 'Clear' (Regular). (3) Withdraw 'Clear'. (4) Withdraw 'Cloudy'. Regular is drawn first to ensure it is not contaminated by the long-acting NPH protein.
rationale.incorrect: Withdrawing NPH before Regular is a safety error because if NPH gets into the Regular vial, it will change the onset time of the short-acting insulin.
clinicalPearls: Only 'Regular' insulin is clear. All other intermediate/long-acting insulins (except analogs like Glargine) are cloudy.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'R-N' (Registered Nurse) = Regular before NPH. Or 'Clear before Cloudy'.

reviewUnits.heading: Insulin Administration Safety
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must verify the doses with another licensed nurse before administration. Long-acting insulins (like Lantus/Glargine) should NEVER be mixed.
